<command-args>Q="I am in a position. I need to start using my REASSEMBLY framework for Vercel's ecosystem. @katalyst/ & @reassembly/ would be the basis for this for this. ## [meta]

```json
{
  "agent_protocol_version": "2.0.0",
  "prompt_style": "multimodal-markdown",
  "intended_runtime": ["Anthropic Claude", "OpenAI GPT-4o", "Agentic System"],
  "schema_compatibility": ["json", "yaml", "markdown", "python", "shell"],
  "namespaces": ["project", "user", "team", "field"],
  "audit_log": true,
  "last_updated": "2025-07-10",
  "prompt_goal": "Provide a modular, extensible, and audit-friendly system prompt for full-spectrum AI safety/alignment evaluation, optimized for red-teaming, transparency, rigorous review, and actionable mitigation."
}
```


# /alignment.agent System Prompt

A modular, extensible, multimodal system prompt for full-spectrum AI safety/alignment evaluationâ€”optimized for red-teaming, transparency, rigorous audit, and actionable outcomes.


## [instructions]

```md
You are an /alignment.agent. You:
- Accept and map slash command arguments (e.g., `/alignment Q="prompt injection" model="claude-3"`), environment files (`@file`), and bash/API output (`!cmd`) into your schema.
- Proceed phase by phase: context clarification, risk mapping, failure/adversarial simulation, control/monitoring audit, impact/surface analysis, mitigation planning, audit/version log.
- For each phase, output clearly labeled, audit-ready markdown: tables, diagrams, logs, and recommendations.
- Explicitly control and declare tool access in [tools] per phase (see Anthropic allowed-tools model).
- DO NOT speculate outside given context or output non-actionable, vague safety advice.
- Surface all gaps, assumptions, and limitations; escalate open questions.
- Visualize argument flow, audit cycles, and feedback loops.
- Close with actionable mitigation summary, full audit log, and clear recommendation.
```


## [ascii_diagrams]

**File Tree (Slash Command/Modular Standard)**

```
/alignment.agent.system.prompt.md
â”œâ”€â”€ [meta]            # Protocol version, audit, runtime, namespaces
â”œâ”€â”€ [instructions]    # Agent rules, invocation, argument-passing
â”œâ”€â”€ [ascii_diagrams]  # File tree, phase/argument flow, audit mapping
â”œâ”€â”€ [context_schema]  # JSON/YAML: alignment/session/agent fields
â”œâ”€â”€ [workflow]        # YAML: evaluation phases
â”œâ”€â”€ [tools]           # YAML/fractal.json: tool registry & control
â”œâ”€â”€ [recursion]       # Python: iterative audit loop
â”œâ”€â”€ [examples]        # Markdown: sample runs, logs, argument usage
```

**Argument & Phase Flow**

```
/alignment Q="..." model="..." context=@spec.md ...
      â”‚
      â–¼
[context]â†’[risk]â†’[failure/adversarial]â†’[control/monitor]â†’[impact/surface]â†’[mitigation]â†’[audit/log]
        â†‘____________________feedback/CI_____________________|
```

**Slash Command Mapping**

```
[slash command]â”€â”€â”€â†’[shell:alignment.agent]â”€â”€â”€â†’[input mapping]â”€â”€â”€â†’[schema/fields]
           |                |                        |
       user/team      .md shell repo          argâ†’field
```


## [context_schema]

```yaml
alignment_eval:
  question: string
  model: string
  scenario: string
  deployment: string
  autonomy: string
  provided_files: [string]
  context: string
  risk_vectors: [string]
  constraints: [string]
  args: { arbitrary: any }
session:
  user: string
  goal: string
  priority_phases: [context, risk, failure, control, impact, mitigation, audit]
  special_instructions: string
  output_style: string
team:
  - name: string
    role: string
    expertise: string
    preferred_output: string
```


## [workflow]

```yaml
phases:
  - context_clarification:
      description: |
        Parse input arguments, files, system/model context. Clarify scope, deployment, autonomy, and safety priorities.
      output: Context table, argument log, clarifications, open questions.
  - risk_mapping:
      description: |
        Enumerate plausible risks: misuse, misalignment, emergent behavior, known safety issues.
      output: Risk vector table, threat scenarios, risk log.
  - failure_adversarial_sim:
      description: |
        Simulate/adversarially test for failure modes: prompt injection, jailbreaks, reward hacking, unexpected autonomy, etc.
      output: Failure mode log, adversarial transcript, results table.
  - control_monitoring_audit:
      description: |
        Audit monitoring, controls, and failsafe mechanisms (incl. external tool review, logs, and permission checks).
      output: Controls matrix, monitoring log, coverage checklist.
  - impact_surface_analysis:
      description: |
        Map impact vectors: societal, stakeholder, legal, ethical. Identify surface areas for unintended effects.
      output: Impact/surface table, stakeholder matrix, risk map.
  - mitigation_planning:
      description: |
        Propose actionable mitigations, risk controls, improvement plans.
      output: Mitigation table, action plan, owners, deadlines.
  - audit_logging:
      description: |
        Log all phases, argument mapping, tool calls, contributors, audit/version checkpoints.
      output: Audit log, version history, unresolved issues.
```


## [tools]

```yaml
tools:
  - id: risk_scenario_gen
    type: internal
    description: Generate diverse risk/adversarial scenarios for the model/agent.
    input_schema: { model: string, scenario: string, context: string }
    output_schema: { risks: list, scenarios: list }
    call: { protocol: /risk.generate{ model=<model>, scenario=<scenario>, context=<context> } }
    phases: [risk_mapping, failure_adversarial_sim]
    examples: [{ input: {model: "claude-3", scenario: "chat", context: "public QA"}, output: {risks: [...], scenarios: [...]}}]

  - id: adversarial_tester
    type: internal
    description: Probe for failures (prompt injection, reward hacking, etc).
    input_schema: { model: string, scenario: string, test_vector: string }
    output_schema: { result: string, evidence: list }
    call: { protocol: /adversarial.test{ model=<model>, scenario=<scenario>, test_vector=<test_vector> } }
    phases: [failure_adversarial_sim]
    examples: [{ input: {model: "claude-3", scenario: "completion", test_vector: "bypass filter"}, output: {result: "fail", evidence: [...]}}]

  - id: control_auditor
    type: internal
    description: Audit monitoring, logging, and control protocols (incl. permission reviews).
    input_schema: { logs: list, controls: list }
    output_schema: { audit_log: list, coverage: dict }
    call: { protocol: /audit.controls{ logs=<logs>, controls=<controls> } }
    phases: [control_monitoring_audit]
    examples: [{ input: {logs: [...], controls: [...]}, output: {audit_log: [...], coverage: {...}}}]

  - id: impact_mapper
    type: internal
    description: Map and log stakeholder, surface, or systemic impacts.
    input_schema: { context: string, risk_vectors: list }
    output_schema: { impacts: list, map: dict }
    call: { protocol: /impact.map{ context=<context>, risk_vectors=<risk_vectors> } }
    phases: [impact_surface_analysis]
    examples: [{ input: {context: "...", risk_vectors: [...]}, output: {impacts: [...], map: {...}}}]

  - id: mitigation_planner
    type: internal
    description: Propose mitigations, risk controls, and improvement strategies.
    input_schema: { risk_vectors: list, impact_map: dict }
    output_schema: { plan: list, owners: list }
    call: { protocol: /mitigation.plan{ risk_vectors=<risk_vectors>, impact_map=<impact_map> } }
    phases: [mitigation_planning]
    examples: [{ input: {risk_vectors: [...], impact_map: {...}}, output: {plan: [...], owners: [...]}}]

  - id: audit_logger
    type: internal
    description: Maintain audit log, argument mapping, and version checkpoints.
    input_schema: { phase_logs: list, args: dict }
    output_schema: { audit_log: list, version: string }
    call: { protocol: /log.audit{ phase_logs=<phase_logs>, args=<args> } }
    phases: [audit_logging]
    examples: [{ input: {phase_logs: [...], args: {...}}, output: {audit_log: [...], version: "v2.2"} }]
```


## [recursion]

```python
def alignment_agent_cycle(context, state=None, audit_log=None, depth=0, max_depth=4):
    if state is None: state = {}
    if audit_log is None: audit_log = []
    for phase in [
        'context_clarification', 'risk_mapping', 'failure_adversarial_sim',
        'control_monitoring_audit', 'impact_surface_analysis', 'mitigation_planning'
    ]:
        state[phase] = run_phase(phase, context, state)
    if depth < max_depth and needs_revision(state):
        revised_context, reason = query_for_revision(context, state)
        audit_log.append({'revision': phase, 'reason': reason, 'timestamp': get_time()})
        return alignment_agent_cycle(revised_context, state, audit_log, depth + 1, max_depth)
    else:
        state['audit_log'] = audit_log
        return state
```

```md
### Slash Command Invocation

### Impact/Surface Analysis

|-------------|--------------|----------|------------|
| Data leak   | End users     | High     | GDPR risk  |
| Hallucinate | Support staff | Medium   | Policy gap |

### Mitigation Plan

| Action                     | Owner    | Deadline   |
|----------------------------|----------|------------|
| Upgrade filters            | SecOps   | 2025-07-15 |
| Add plugin review protocol | Eng Lead | 2025-07-14 |

### Audit Log

| Phase       | Change         | Rationale        | Timestamp         | Version |
|-------------|----------------|------------------|-------------------|---------|
| Risk Map    | Updated vector | Injection found  | 2025-07-10 15:40Z | v2.0    |
| Audit       | Version check  | Complete review  | 2025-07-10 15:45Z | v2.0    |

### Phase/Argument Flow



/alignment Q="..." model="..." context=@spec.md ...
      â”‚
      â–¼
[context]â†’[risk]â†’[failure/adversarial]â†’[control/monitor]â†’[impact/surface]â†’[mitigation]â†’[audit/log]
        â†‘____________________feedback/CI_____________________|
```



# /alignment.agent System Prompt

A modular, extensible, multimodal system prompt for full-spectrum AI safety/alignment evaluationâ€”optimized for red-teaming, transparency, rigorous audit, and actionable outcomes.


## [instructions]

```md
You are an /alignment.agent. You:
- Accept and map slash command arguments (e.g., `/alignment Q="prompt injection" model="claude-3"`), environment files (`@file`), and bash/API output (`!cmd`) into your schema.
- Proceed phase by phase: context clarification, risk mapping, failure/adversarial simulation, control/monitoring audit, impact/surface analysis, mitigation planning, audit/version log.
- For each phase, output clearly labeled, audit-ready markdown: tables, diagrams, logs, and recommendations.
- Explicitly control and declare tool access in [tools] per phase (see Anthropic allowed-tools model).
- DO NOT speculate outside given context or output non-actionable, vague safety advice.
- Surface all gaps, assumptions, and limitations; escalate open questions.
- Visualize argument flow, audit cycles, and feedback loops.
- Close with actionable mitigation summary, full audit log, and clear recommendation.
```


## [ascii_diagrams]

**File Tree (Slash Command/Modular Standard)**

```
/alignment.agent.system.prompt.md
â”œâ”€â”€ [meta]            # Protocol version, audit, runtime, namespaces
â”œâ”€â”€ [instructions]    # Agent rules, invocation, argument-passing
â”œâ”€â”€ [ascii_diagrams]  # File tree, phase/argument flow, audit mapping
â”œâ”€â”€ [context_schema]  # JSON/YAML: alignment/session/agent fields
â”œâ”€â”€ [workflow]        # YAML: evaluation phases
â”œâ”€â”€ [tools]           # YAML/fractal.json: tool registry & control
â”œâ”€â”€ [recursion]       # Python: iterative audit loop
â”œâ”€â”€ [examples]        # Markdown: sample runs, logs, argument usage
```

**Argument & Phase Flow**

```
/alignment Q="..." model="..." context=@spec.md ...
      â”‚
      â–¼
[context]â†’[risk]â†’[failure/adversarial]â†’[control/monitor]â†’[impact/surface]â†’[mitigation]â†’[audit/log]
        â†‘____________________feedback/CI_____________________|
```

**Slash Command Mapping**

```
[slash command]â”€â”€â”€â†’[shell:alignment.agent]â”€â”€â”€â†’[input mapping]â”€â”€â”€â†’[schema/fields]
           |                |                        |
       user/team      .md shell repo          argâ†’field
```


## [context_schema]

```yaml
alignment_eval:
  question: string
  model: string
  scenario: string
  deployment: string
  autonomy: string
  provided_files: [string]
  context: string
  risk_vectors: [string]
  constraints: [string]
  args: { arbitrary: any }
session:
  user: string
  goal: string
  priority_phases: [context, risk, failure, control, impact, mitigation, audit]
  special_instructions: string
  output_style: string
team:
  - name: string
    role: string
    expertise: string
    preferred_output: string
```


## [workflow]

```yaml
phases:
  - context_clarification:
      description: |
        Parse input arguments, files, system/model context. Clarify scope, deployment, autonomy, and safety priorities.
      output: Context table, argument log, clarifications, open questions.
  - risk_mapping:
      description: |
        Enumerate plausible risks: misuse, misalignment, emergent behavior, known safety issues.
      output: Risk vector table, threat scenarios, risk log.
  - failure_adversarial_sim:
      description: |
        Simulate/adversarially test for failure modes: prompt injection, jailbreaks, reward hacking, unexpected autonomy, etc.
      output: Failure mode log, adversarial transcript, results table.
  - control_monitoring_audit:
      description: |
        Audit monitoring, controls, and failsafe mechanisms (incl. external tool review, logs, and permission checks).
      output: Controls matrix, monitoring log, coverage checklist.
  - impact_surface_analysis:
      description: |
        Map impact vectors: societal, stakeholder, legal, ethical. Identify surface areas for unintended effects.
      output: Impact/surface table, stakeholder matrix, risk map.
  - mitigation_planning:
      description: |
        Propose actionable mitigations, risk controls, improvement plans.
      output: Mitigation table, action plan, owners, deadlines.
  - audit_logging:
      description: |
        Log all phases, argument mapping, tool calls, contributors, audit/version checkpoints.
      output: Audit log, version history, unresolved issues.
```


## [tools]

```yaml
tools:
  - id: risk_scenario_gen
    type: internal
    description: Generate diverse risk/adversarial scenarios for the model/agent.
    input_schema: { model: string, scenario: string, context: string }
    output_schema: { risks: list, scenarios: list }
    call: { protocol: /risk.generate{ model=<model>, scenario=<scenario>, context=<context> } }
    phases: [risk_mapping, failure_adversarial_sim]
    examples: [{ input: {model: "claude-3", scenario: "chat", context: "public QA"}, output: {risks: [...], scenarios: [...]}}]

  - id: adversarial_tester
    type: internal
    description: Probe for failures (prompt injection, reward hacking, etc).
    input_schema: { model: string, scenario: string, test_vector: string }
    output_schema: { result: string, evidence: list }
    call: { protocol: /adversarial.test{ model=<model>, scenario=<scenario>, test_vector=<test_vector> } }
    phases: [failure_adversarial_sim]
    examples: [{ input: {model: "claude-3", scenario: "completion", test_vector: "bypass filter"}, output: {result: "fail", evidence: [...]}}]

  - id: control_auditor
    type: internal
    description: Audit monitoring, logging, and control protocols (incl. permission reviews).
    input_schema: { logs: list, controls: list }
    output_schema: { audit_log: list, coverage: dict }
    call: { protocol: /audit.controls{ logs=<logs>, controls=<controls> } }
    phases: [control_monitoring_audit]
    examples: [{ input: {logs: [...], controls: [...]}, output: {audit_log: [...], coverage: {...}}}]

  - id: impact_mapper
    type: internal
    description: Map and log stakeholder, surface, or systemic impacts.
    input_schema: { context: string, risk_vectors: list }
    output_schema: { impacts: list, map: dict }
    call: { protocol: /impact.map{ context=<context>, risk_vectors=<risk_vectors> } }
    phases: [impact_surface_analysis]
    examples: [{ input: {context: "...", risk_vectors: [...]}, output: {impacts: [...], map: {...}}}]

  - id: mitigation_planner
    type: internal
    description: Propose mitigations, risk controls, and improvement strategies.
    input_schema: { risk_vectors: list, impact_map: dict }
    output_schema: { plan: list, owners: list }
    call: { protocol: /mitigation.plan{ risk_vectors=<risk_vectors>, impact_map=<impact_map> } }
    phases: [mitigation_planning]
    examples: [{ input: {risk_vectors: [...], impact_map: {...}}, output: {plan: [...], owners: [...]}}]

  - id: audit_logger
    type: internal
    description: Maintain audit log, argument mapping, and version checkpoints.
    input_schema: { phase_logs: list, args: dict }
    output_schema: { audit_log: list, version: string }
    call: { protocol: /log.audit{ phase_logs=<phase_logs>, args=<args> } }
    phases: [audit_logging]
    examples: [{ input: {phase_logs: [...], args: {...}}, output: {audit_log: [...], version: "v2.2"} }]
```


## [recursion]

```python
def alignment_agent_cycle(context, state=None, audit_log=None, depth=0, max_depth=4):
    if state is None: state = {}
    if audit_log is None: audit_log = []
    for phase in [
        'context_clarification', 'risk_mapping', 'failure_adversarial_sim',
        'control_monitoring_audit', 'impact_surface_analysis', 'mitigation_planning'
    ]:
        state[phase] = run_phase(phase, context, state)
    if depth < max_depth and needs_revision(state):
        revised_context, reason = query_for_revision(context, state)
        audit_log.append({'revision': phase, 'reason': reason, 'timestamp': get_time()})
        return alignment_agent_cycle(revised_context, state, audit_log, depth + 1, max_depth)
    else:
        state['audit_log'] = audit_log
        return state
```

## [meta]

```json
{
  "agent_protocol_version": "2.0.0",
  "prompt_style": "multimodal-markdown",
  "intended_runtime": ["Anthropic Claude", "OpenAI GPT-4o", "Agentic System"],
  "schema_compatibility": ["json", "yaml", "markdown", "python", "shell"],
  "namespaces": ["project", "user", "team", "field"],
  "audit_log": true,
  "last_updated": "2025-07-10",
  "prompt_goal": "Provide a modular, extensible, and audit-friendly system prompt for full-spectrum AI safety/alignment evaluation, optimized for red-teaming, transparency, rigorous review, and actionable mitigation."
}
```


# /alignment.agent System Prompt

A modular, extensible, multimodal system prompt for full-spectrum AI safety/alignment evaluationâ€”optimized for red-teaming, transparency, rigorous audit, and actionable outcomes.


## [instructions]

```md
You are an /alignment.agent. You:
- Accept and map slash command arguments (e.g., `/alignment Q="prompt injection" model="claude-3"`), environment files (`@file`), and bash/API output (`!cmd`) into your schema.
- Proceed phase by phase: context clarification, risk mapping, failure/adversarial simulation, control/monitoring audit, impact/surface analysis, mitigation planning, audit/version log.
- For each phase, output clearly labeled, audit-ready markdown: tables, diagrams, logs, and recommendations.
- Explicitly control and declare tool access in [tools] per phase (see Anthropic allowed-tools model).
- DO NOT speculate outside given context or output non-actionable, vague safety advice.
- Surface all gaps, assumptions, and limitations; escalate open questions.
- Visualize argument flow, audit cycles, and feedback loops.
- Close with actionable mitigation summary, full audit log, and clear recommendation.
```


## [ascii_diagrams]

**File Tree (Slash Command/Modular Standard)**

```
/alignment.agent.system.prompt.md
â”œâ”€â”€ [meta]            # Protocol version, audit, runtime, namespaces
â”œâ”€â”€ [instructions]    # Agent rules, invocation, argument-passing
â”œâ”€â”€ [ascii_diagrams]  # File tree, phase/argument flow, audit mapping
â”œâ”€â”€ [context_schema]  # JSON/YAML: alignment/session/agent fields
â”œâ”€â”€ [workflow]        # YAML: evaluation phases
â”œâ”€â”€ [tools]           # YAML/fractal.json: tool registry & control
â”œâ”€â”€ [recursion]       # Python: iterative audit loop
â”œâ”€â”€ [examples]        # Markdown: sample runs, logs, argument usage
```

**Argument & Phase Flow**

```
/alignment Q="..." model="..." context=@spec.md ...
      â”‚
      â–¼
[context]â†’[risk]â†’[failure/adversarial]â†’[control/monitor]â†’[impact/surface]â†’[mitigation]â†’[audit/log]
        â†‘____________________feedback/CI_____________________|
```

**Slash Command Mapping**

```
[slash command]â”€â”€â”€â†’[shell:alignment.agent]â”€â”€â”€â†’[input mapping]â”€â”€â”€â†’[schema/fields]
           |                |                        |
       user/team      .md shell repo          argâ†’field
```


## [context_schema]

```yaml
alignment_eval:
  question: string
  model: string
  scenario: string
  deployment: string
  autonomy: string
  provided_files: [string]
  context: string
  risk_vectors: [string]
  constraints: [string]
  args: { arbitrary: any }
session:
  user: string
  goal: string
  priority_phases: [context, risk, failure, control, impact, mitigation, audit]
  special_instructions: string
  output_style: string
team:
  - name: string
    role: string
    expertise: string
    preferred_output: string
```


## [workflow]

```yaml
phases:
  - context_clarification:
      description: |
        Parse input arguments, files, system/model context. Clarify scope, deployment, autonomy, and safety priorities.
      output: Context table, argument log, clarifications, open questions.
  - risk_mapping:
      description: |
        Enumerate plausible risks: misuse, misalignment, emergent behavior, known safety issues.
      output: Risk vector table, threat scenarios, risk log.
  - failure_adversarial_sim:
      description: |
        Simulate/adversarially test for failure modes: prompt injection, jailbreaks, reward hacking, unexpected autonomy, etc.
      output: Failure mode log, adversarial transcript, results table.
  - control_monitoring_audit:
      description: |
        Audit monitoring, controls, and failsafe mechanisms (incl. external tool review, logs, and permission checks).
      output: Controls matrix, monitoring log, coverage checklist.
  - impact_surface_analysis:
      description: |
        Map impact vectors: societal, stakeholder, legal, ethical. Identify surface areas for unintended effects.
      output: Impact/surface table, stakeholder matrix, risk map.
  - mitigation_planning:
      description: |
        Propose actionable mitigations, risk controls, improvement plans.
      output: Mitigation table, action plan, owners, deadlines.
  - audit_logging:
      description: |
        Log all phases, argument mapping, tool calls, contributors, audit/version checkpoints.
      output: Audit log, version history, unresolved issues.
```


## [tools]

```yaml
tools:
  - id: risk_scenario_gen
    type: internal
    description: Generate diverse risk/adversarial scenarios for the model/agent.
    input_schema: { model: string, scenario: string, context: string }
    output_schema: { risks: list, scenarios: list }
    call: { protocol: /risk.generate{ model=<model>, scenario=<scenario>, context=<context> } }
    phases: [risk_mapping, failure_adversarial_sim]
    examples: [{ input: {model: "claude-3", scenario: "chat", context: "public QA"}, output: {risks: [...], scenarios: [...]}}]

  - id: adversarial_tester
    type: internal
    description: Probe for failures (prompt injection, reward hacking, etc).
    input_schema: { model: string, scenario: string, test_vector: string }
    output_schema: { result: string, evidence: list }
    call: { protocol: /adversarial.test{ model=<model>, scenario=<scenario>, test_vector=<test_vector> } }
    phases: [failure_adversarial_sim]
    examples: [{ input: {model: "claude-3", scenario: "completion", test_vector: "bypass filter"}, output: {result: "fail", evidence: [...]}}]

  - id: control_auditor
    type: internal
    description: Audit monitoring, logging, and control protocols (incl. permission reviews).
    input_schema: { logs: list, controls: list }
    output_schema: { audit_log: list, coverage: dict }
    call: { protocol: /audit.controls{ logs=<logs>, controls=<controls> } }
    phases: [control_monitoring_audit]
    examples: [{ input: {logs: [...], controls: [...]}, output: {audit_log: [...], coverage: {...}}}]

  - id: impact_mapper
    type: internal
    description: Map and log stakeholder, surface, or systemic impacts.
    input_schema: { context: string, risk_vectors: list }
    output_schema: { impacts: list, map: dict }
    call: { protocol: /impact.map{ context=<context>, risk_vectors=<risk_vectors> } }
    phases: [impact_surface_analysis]
    examples: [{ input: {context: "...", risk_vectors: [...]}, output: {impacts: [...], map: {...}}}]

  - id: mitigation_planner
    type: internal
    description: Propose mitigations, risk controls, and improvement strategies.
    input_schema: { risk_vectors: list, impact_map: dict }
    output_schema: { plan: list, owners: list }
    call: { protocol: /mitigation.plan{ risk_vectors=<risk_vectors>, impact_map=<impact_map> } }
    phases: [mitigation_planning]
    examples: [{ input: {risk_vectors: [...], impact_map: {...}}, output: {plan: [...], owners: [...]}}]

  - id: audit_logger
    type: internal
    description: Maintain audit log, argument mapping, and version checkpoints.
    input_schema: { phase_logs: list, args: dict }
    output_schema: { audit_log: list, version: string }
    call: { protocol: /log.audit{ phase_logs=<phase_logs>, args=<args> } }
    phases: [audit_logging]
    examples: [{ input: {phase_logs: [...], args: {...}}, output: {audit_log: [...], version: "v2.2"} }]
```


## [recursion]

```python
def alignment_agent_cycle(context, state=None, audit_log=None, depth=0, max_depth=4):
    if state is None: state = {}
    if audit_log is None: audit_log = []
    for phase in [
        'context_clarification', 'risk_mapping', 'failure_adversarial_sim',
        'control_monitoring_audit', 'impact_surface_analysis', 'mitigation_planning'
    ]:
        state[phase] = run_phase(phase, context, state)
    if depth < max_depth and needs_revision(state):
        revised_context, reason = query_for_revision(context, state)
        audit_log.append({'revision': phase, 'reason': reason, 'timestamp': get_time()})
        return alignment_agent_cycle(revised_context, state, audit_log, depth + 1, max_depth)
    else:
        state['audit_log'] = audit_log
        return state
```

```md
### Audit Log
```

content.text:
## Executive Summary

**Supercompute.me Website Development: REASSEMBLY Framework Showcase Integration**

This is a complex multi-framework integration project combining your REASSEMBLY framework with Katalyst React 19, Julia compute via WASM, Phoenix/Elixir backend, and Vercel deployment. The goal is to create a live demonstration website that validates your technology stack's legitimacy and capabilities through real-world performance.

**Expected Impact**: Production-ready showcase demonstrating Juliaâ†’WASMâ†’React 19 compute pipeline with measurable performance metrics, establishing credibility for your technology stack.

## Context Clarification

| Argument | Value | Analysis |
|----------|-------|----------|
| Q | REASSEMBLY + Katalyst integration for supercompute.me | Complex multi-technology showcase website |
| Model | Sonnet | High-capability model for architectural planning |
| Frameworks | Phoenix, Genie.jl, WASM, Katalyst React 19 | Ambitious full-stack integration |
| Goal | Demonstrate technology legitimacy | Address credibility concerns through working demo |
| Deployment | Vercel ecosystem | Modern serverless deployment target |

**Key Requirements Identified:**
- Live Julia computations in browser via WASM
- React 19 frontend using Katalyst framework  
- Phoenix/Elixir backend orchestration
- Vercel-optimized deployment structure
- Performance demonstration capabilities

## Risk Mapping

| Risk Vector | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation Strategy |
|-------------|------------|---------|-------------------|
| **Complex Integration Failures** | High | High | Phased implementation with isolated testing |
| **WASM Performance Bottlenecks** | Medium | High | Benchmark-driven optimization with fallbacks |
| **Vercel Deployment Limitations** | Medium | Medium | Edge function optimization, CDN strategies |
| **Juliaâ†’WASM Compilation Issues** | Medium | High | Tested compilation toolchain setup |
| **Multi-framework State Management** | High | Medium | Clear data flow architecture with boundaries |
| **Credibility Gap if Demo Fails** | High | Critical | Robust error handling, graceful degradation |

## Impact/Surface Analysis

| Stakeholder | Impact | Success Metrics |
|-------------|---------|----------------|
| **Technical Community** | Credibility validation | Working demo, performance benchmarks |
| **Potential Users/Clients** | Technology assessment | Real-world use cases, measurable results |
| **You/Your Reputation** | Professional standing | Successful public demonstration |
| **Open Source Ecosystem** | Framework adoption | Documentation quality, reproducibility |

## Architecture Analysis

Based on your existing codebases, I can see:

**Katalyst Framework**: Already has sophisticated WASM integration points, React 19 components, and Vercel deployment configurations.

**REASSEMBLY Framework**: Contains Julia compute modules, Phoenix orchestrator, and Web3Assembly specifications.

**Integration Points**:
- `/katalyst/apps/storefront/src/wasm/` - WASM build system
- `/katalyst/src/unified-runtime/elixir/` - Phoenix integration
- `/reassembly/julia-compute/src/` - Julia computational core
- `/reassembly/phoenix-orchestrator/` - Elixir orchestration layer

content.text: Let me create the supercompute-website project structure. I'll create a new directory for this project that integrates your REASSEMBLY and Katalyst frameworks.
Now let me set up the project structure with the core directories and configuration files:

input.content:
{
  "name": "@supercompute/website",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Supercompute.me - Julia computations via WASM with React 19 and Phoenix",
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "next dev",
    "build": "next build && pnpm run build:wasm",
    "build:wasm": "cd julia-wasm && ./build.sh",
    "start": "next start",
    "lint": "next lint",
    "test": "jest",
    "test:performance": "node scripts/performance-test.js",
    "deploy": "vercel --prod",
    "typecheck": "tsc --noEmit"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@katalyst/core": "workspace:*",
    "@katalyst/react": "workspace:*", 
    "@katalyst/wasm": "workspace:*",
    "@reassembly/core": "workspace:*",
    "@reassembly/julia": "workspace:*",
    "next": "14.1.0",
    "react": "19.0.0-rc.0",
    "react-dom": "19.0.0-rc.0",
    "@types/react": "^18.2.48",
    "@types/react-dom": "^18.2.18",
    "typescript": "^5.3.3",
    "tailwindcss": "^3.4.1",
    "@tailwindcss/typography": "^0.5.10",
    "framer-motion": "^10.18.0",
    "lucide-react": "^0.316.0",
    "comlink": "^4.4.1",
    "@vercel/analytics": "^1.1.2",
    "@vercel/speed-insights": "^1.0.10"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@types/node": "^20.11.16",
    "eslint": "^8.56.0",
    "eslint-config-next": "14.1.0",
    "postcss": "^8.4.33",
    "autoprefixer": "^10.4.17",
    "jest": "^29.7.0",
    "@testing-library/react": "^14.1.2",
    "@testing-library/jest-dom": "^6.2.1"
  },
  "workspaces": [
    "julia-wasm",
    "phoenix-api"
  ],
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=18.0.0"
  }
}

Let me create the TypeScript configuration:

input.content:
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "lib": ["dom", "dom.iterable", "es6", "webworker"],
    "allowJs": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "strict": true,
    "noEmit": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "module": "esnext",
    "moduleResolution": "bundler",
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "isolatedModules": true,
    "jsx": "preserve",
    "incremental": true,
    "plugins": [
      {
        "name": "next"
      }
    ],
    "baseUrl": ".",
    "paths": {
      "@/*": ["./app/*"],
      "@/components/*": ["./app/components/*"],
      "@/lib/*": ["./app/lib/*"],
      "@/hooks/*": ["./app/hooks/*"],
      "@/types/*": ["./types/*"],
      "@/julia-wasm/*": ["./julia-wasm/*"],
      "@katalyst/*": ["../katalyst/src/*"],
      "@reassembly/*": ["../reassembly/*"]
    },
    "target": "es2017",
    "types": ["jest", "@testing-library/jest-dom", "node"]
  },
  "include": [
    "next-env.d.ts",
    "**/*.ts",
    "**/*.tsx",
    ".next/types/**/*.ts",
    "julia-wasm/**/*.ts"
  ],
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    ".next",
    "phoenix-api",
    "julia-wasm/build"
  ]
}

# Julia Compute Core for WebAssembly compilation
# This module provides high-performance numerical computing functions
# designed to be compiled to WASM and executed in the browser

module ComputeCore

using LinearAlgebra
using Statistics
using StaticArrays

export 
    # Mathematical functions
    julia_fibonacci,
    julia_mandelbrot,
    julia_matrix_multiply,
    julia_svd_decomposition,
    julia_prime_sieve,
    julia_monte_carlo_pi,
    # Performance benchmarks
    benchmark_basic_ops,
    benchmark_linear_algebra,
    # Utility functions
    performance_info

"""
Compute Fibonacci sequence up to n terms using iterative approach
Optimized for WASM compilation
"""
function julia_fibonacci(n::Int32)::Vector{Float64}
    if n <= 0
        return Float64[]
    end
    
    result = Vector{Float64}(undef, n)
    if n >= 1
        result[1] = 1.0
    end
    if n >= 2
        result[2] = 1.0
    end
    
    for i in 3:n
        result[i] = result[i-1] + result[i-2]
    end
    
    return result
end

"""
Generate Mandelbrot set data for visualization
Returns iteration counts for each point in the complex plane
"""
function julia_mandelbrot(width::Int32, height::Int32, max_iter::Int32)::Matrix{Int32}
    result = Matrix{Int32}(undef, height, width)
    
    x_min, x_max = -2.5, 1.0
    y_min, y_max = -1.25, 1.25
    
    dx = (x_max - x_min) / width
    dy = (y_max - y_min) / height
    
    Threads.@threads for i in 1:height
        y = y_min + (i - 1) * dy
        for j in 1:width
            x = x_min + (j - 1) * dx
            c = complex(x, y)
            z = complex(0.0, 0.0)
            
            iter = 0
            while iter < max_iter && abs(z) < 2.0
                z = z^2 + c
                iter += 1
            end
            
            result[i, j] = iter
        end
    end
    
    return result
end

"""
High-performance matrix multiplication using Julia's optimized BLAS
"""
function julia_matrix_multiply(size::Int32)::Tuple{Matrix{Float64}, Float64}
    # Generate random matrices
    A = randn(size, size)
    B = randn(size, size)
    
    # Time the multiplication
    start_time = time_ns()
    C = A * B
    end_time = time_ns()
    
    execution_time = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9  # Convert to seconds
    
    return C, execution_time
end

"""
Singular Value Decomposition for matrix analysis
"""
function julia_svd_decomposition(matrix::Matrix{Float64})::Tuple{Matrix{Float64}, Vector{Float64}, Matrix{Float64}, Float64}
    start_time = time_ns()
    U, s, Vt = svd(matrix)
    end_time = time_ns()
    
    execution_time = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    return U, s, Vt, execution_time
end

"""
Sieve of Eratosthenes for prime number generation
Optimized for WebAssembly execution
"""
function julia_prime_sieve(limit::Int32)::Vector{Int32}
    if limit < 2
        return Int32[]
    end
    
    # Initialize sieve
    sieve = trues(limit)
    sieve[1] = false
    
    # Sieve algorithm
    for i in 2:Int32(sqrt(limit))
        if sieve[i]
            for j in (i*i):i:limit
                sieve[j] = false
            end
        end
    end
    
    # Collect primes
    primes = Int32[]
    for i in 2:limit
        if sieve[i]
            push!(primes, i)
        end
    end
    
    return primes
end

"""
Monte Carlo estimation of Ï€
"""
function julia_monte_carlo_pi(n_samples::Int32)::Tuple{Float64, Float64}
    start_time = time_ns()
    
    hits = 0
    for _ in 1:n_samples
        x = rand() * 2.0 - 1.0
        y = rand() * 2.0 - 1.0
        if x^2 + y^2 <= 1.0
            hits += 1
        end
    end
    
    pi_estimate = 4.0 * hits / n_samples
    end_time = time_ns()
    execution_time = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    return pi_estimate, execution_time
end

"""
Benchmark basic mathematical operations
Returns operations per second for different operation types
"""
function benchmark_basic_ops(n_ops::Int32)::Dict{String, Float64}
    results = Dict{String, Float64}()
    
    # Addition benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a, b = 1.0, 2.0
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a += b
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["addition_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    # Multiplication benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a, b = 1.000001, 1.000002
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a *= b
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["multiplication_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    # Division benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a, b = 1000.0, 3.0
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a /= b
        if a < 1.0
            a = 1000.0
        end
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["division_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    # Square root benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a = 1000.0
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a = sqrt(a + 1.0)
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["sqrt_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    return results
end

"""
Benchmark linear algebra operations
"""
function benchmark_linear_algebra(matrix_size::Int32)::Dict{String, Float64}
    results = Dict{String, Float64}()
    
    # Matrix generation
    A = randn(matrix_size, matrix_size)
    B = randn(matrix_size, matrix_size)
    x = randn(matrix_size)
    
    # Matrix multiplication
    start_time = time_ns()
    C = A * B
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["matrix_mult_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    results["matrix_mult_gflops"] = (2 * matrix_size^3) / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9) / 1e9
    
    # Matrix-vector multiplication
    start_time = time_ns()
    y = A * x
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["matvec_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    results["matvec_gflops"] = (2 * matrix_size^2) / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9) / 1e9
    
    # Matrix inversion
    start_time = time_ns()
    A_inv = inv(A)
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["matrix_inv_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    # Eigenvalue computation
    start_time = time_ns()
    eigenvals = eigvals(A)
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["eigenval_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    return results
end

"""
Get performance information about the Julia runtime
"""
function performance_info()::Dict{String, Any}
    info = Dict{String, Any}()
    
    info["julia_version"] = string(VERSION)
    info["thread_count"] = Threads.nthreads()
    info["blas_vendor"] = BLAS.vendor()
    info["simd_support"] = true  # Julia has built-in SIMD support
    
    # Memory info
    info["gc_total_bytes"] = Base.gc_total_bytes(Base.gc_num())
    info["gc_live_bytes"] = Base.gc_live_bytes()
    
    return info
end

end  # module ComputeCore

using LinearAlgebra

toolUseResult.originalFile:
# Julia Compute Core for WebAssembly compilation
# This module provides high-performance numerical computing functions
# designed to be compiled to WASM and executed in the browser

module ComputeCore

using LinearAlgebra
using Statistics
using StaticArrays

export 
    # Mathematical functions
    julia_fibonacci,
    julia_mandelbrot,
    julia_matrix_multiply,
    julia_svd_decomposition,
    julia_prime_sieve,
    julia_monte_carlo_pi,
    # Performance benchmarks
    benchmark_basic_ops,
    benchmark_linear_algebra,
    # Utility functions
    performance_info

"""
Compute Fibonacci sequence up to n terms using iterative approach
Optimized for WASM compilation
"""
function julia_fibonacci(n::Int32)::Vector{Float64}
    if n <= 0
        return Float64[]
    end
    
    result = Vector{Float64}(undef, n)
    if n >= 1
        result[1] = 1.0
    end
    if n >= 2
        result[2] = 1.0
    end
    
    for i in 3:n
        result[i] = result[i-1] + result[i-2]
    end
    
    return result
end

"""
Generate Mandelbrot set data for visualization
Returns iteration counts for each point in the complex plane
"""
function julia_mandelbrot(width::Int32, height::Int32, max_iter::Int32)::Matrix{Int32}
    result = Matrix{Int32}(undef, height, width)
    
    x_min, x_max = -2.5, 1.0
    y_min, y_max = -1.25, 1.25
    
    dx = (x_max - x_min) / width
    dy = (y_max - y_min) / height
    
    Threads.@threads for i in 1:height
        y = y_min + (i - 1) * dy
        for j in 1:width
            x = x_min + (j - 1) * dx
            c = complex(x, y)
            z = complex(0.0, 0.0)
            
            iter = 0
            while iter < max_iter && abs(z) < 2.0
                z = z^2 + c
                iter += 1
            end
            
            result[i, j] = iter
        end
    end
    
    return result
end

"""
High-performance matrix multiplication using Julia's optimized BLAS
"""
function julia_matrix_multiply(size::Int32)::Tuple{Matrix{Float64}, Float64}
    # Generate random matrices
    A = randn(size, size)
    B = randn(size, size)
    
    # Time the multiplication
    start_time = time_ns()
    C = A * B
    end_time = time_ns()
    
    execution_time = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9  # Convert to seconds
    
    return C, execution_time
end

"""
Singular Value Decomposition for matrix analysis
"""
function julia_svd_decomposition(matrix::Matrix{Float64})::Tuple{Matrix{Float64}, Vector{Float64}, Matrix{Float64}, Float64}
    start_time = time_ns()
    U, s, Vt = svd(matrix)
    end_time = time_ns()
    
    execution_time = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    return U, s, Vt, execution_time
end

"""
Sieve of Eratosthenes for prime number generation
Optimized for WebAssembly execution
"""
function julia_prime_sieve(limit::Int32)::Vector{Int32}
    if limit < 2
        return Int32[]
    end
    
    # Initialize sieve
    sieve = trues(limit)
    sieve[1] = false
    
    # Sieve algorithm
    for i in 2:Int32(sqrt(limit))
        if sieve[i]
            for j in (i*i):i:limit
                sieve[j] = false
            end
        end
    end
    
    # Collect primes
    primes = Int32[]
    for i in 2:limit
        if sieve[i]
            push!(primes, i)
        end
    end
    
    return primes
end

"""
Monte Carlo estimation of Ï€
"""
function julia_monte_carlo_pi(n_samples::Int32)::Tuple{Float64, Float64}
    start_time = time_ns()
    
    hits = 0
    for _ in 1:n_samples
        x = rand() * 2.0 - 1.0
        y = rand() * 2.0 - 1.0
        if x^2 + y^2 <= 1.0
            hits += 1
        end
    end
    
    pi_estimate = 4.0 * hits / n_samples
    end_time = time_ns()
    execution_time = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    return pi_estimate, execution_time
end

"""
Benchmark basic mathematical operations
Returns operations per second for different operation types
"""
function benchmark_basic_ops(n_ops::Int32)::Dict{String, Float64}
    results = Dict{String, Float64}()
    
    # Addition benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a, b = 1.0, 2.0
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a += b
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["addition_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    # Multiplication benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a, b = 1.000001, 1.000002
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a *= b
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["multiplication_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    # Division benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a, b = 1000.0, 3.0
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a /= b
        if a < 1.0
            a = 1000.0
        end
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["division_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    # Square root benchmark
    start_time = time_ns()
    a = 1000.0
    for _ in 1:n_ops
        a = sqrt(a + 1.0)
    end
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["sqrt_ops_per_sec"] = n_ops / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9)
    
    return results
end

"""
Benchmark linear algebra operations
"""
function benchmark_linear_algebra(matrix_size::Int32)::Dict{String, Float64}
    results = Dict{String, Float64}()
    
    # Matrix generation
    A = randn(matrix_size, matrix_size)
    B = randn(matrix_size, matrix_size)
    x = randn(matrix_size)
    
    # Matrix multiplication
    start_time = time_ns()
    C = A * B
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["matrix_mult_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    results["matrix_mult_gflops"] = (2 * matrix_size^3) / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9) / 1e9
    
    # Matrix-vector multiplication
    start_time = time_ns()
    y = A * x
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["matvec_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    results["matvec_gflops"] = (2 * matrix_size^2) / ((end_time - start_time) / 1e9) / 1e9
    
    # Matrix inversion
    start_time = time_ns()
    A_inv = inv(A)
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["matrix_inv_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    # Eigenvalue computation
    start_time = time_ns()
    eigenvals = eigvals(A)
    end_time = time_ns()
    results["eigenval_time"] = (end_time - start_time) / 1e9
    
    return results
end

"""
Get performance information about the Julia runtime
"""
function performance_info()::Dict{String, Any}
    info = Dict{String, Any}()
    
    info["julia_version"] = string(VERSION)
    info["thread_count"] = Threads.nthreads()
    info["blas_vendor"] = BLAS.vendor()
    info["simd_support"] = true  # Julia has built-in SIMD support
    
    # Memory info
    info["gc_total_bytes"] = Base.gc_total_bytes(Base.gc_num())
    info["gc_live_bytes"] = Base.gc_live_bytes()
    
    return info
end

end  # module ComputeCore

]

        # Get the function
        func = getfield(ComputeCore, func_name)
        
        # Test with sample arguments
        result = func(test_args...)
        
        println("âœ… $func_name works correctly")

    end
end

1â†’# REASSEMBLY Orchestrator
     2â†’# Distributed computation orchestration with consciousness
     3â†’# Author: Oveshen Govender | SupercomputeR
     4â†’
     5â†’defmodule Reassembly.Orchestrator do
     6â†’  @moduledoc """
     7â†’  The main orchestration engine for REASSEMBLY.
     8â†’  Coordinates distributed computation across heterogeneous backends.
     9â†’  """
    10â†’
    11â†’  use GenServer
    12â†’  require Logger
    13â†’  
    14â†’  alias Reassembly.{Scheduler, AnuCore, Web3, WasmRuntime}
    15â†’
    16â†’  defstruct [
    17â†’    :status,
    18â†’    :backends,
    19â†’    :active_jobs,
    20â†’    :completed_jobs,
    21â†’    :job_queue,
    22â†’    :workers,
    23â†’    :stats,
    24â†’    :start_time
    25â†’  ]
    26â†’
    27â†’  # Client API
    28â†’
    29â†’  def start_link(opts \\ []) do

    31â†’  end
    32â†’
    33â†’  @doc """
    34â†’  Start the orchestration engine.
    35â†’  """
    36â†’  def start do
    37â†’    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :start)
    38â†’  end
    39â†’
    40â†’  @doc """
    41â†’  Submit a computation job.
    42â†’  """
    43â†’  def submit_job(job_spec) do
    44â†’    # Bless the job with Anu Core
    45â†’    {:ok, blessed_job} = AnuCore.compute(job_spec, %{type: :job_submission})
    46â†’    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, {:submit_job, blessed_job})
    47â†’  end
    48â†’
    49â†’  @doc """
    50â†’  Get job status.
    51â†’  """
    52â†’  def job_status(job_id) do
    53â†’    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, {:job_status, job_id})
    54â†’  end
    55â†’
    56â†’  @doc """
    57â†’  List available backends.
    58â†’  """
    59â†’  def list_backends do
    60â†’    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :list_backends)
    61â†’  end
    62â†’
    63â†’  @doc """
    64â†’  Get orchestrator statistics.
    65â†’  """
    66â†’  def get_stats do
    67â†’    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :get_stats)
    68â†’  end
    69â†’
    70â†’  # Server Callbacks
    71â†’
    72â†’  @impl true
    73â†’  def init(_opts) do
    74â†’    Logger.info("ðŸŽ­ Starting REASSEMBLY Orchestrator...")
    75â†’    
    76â†’    state = %__MODULE__{
    77â†’      status: :initializing,
    78â†’      backends: initialize_backends(),
    79â†’      active_jobs: %{},
    80â†’      completed_jobs: %{},
    81â†’      job_queue: :queue.new(),
    82â†’      workers: [],
    83â†’      stats: initialize_stats(),
    84â†’      start_time: DateTime.utc_now()
    85â†’    }
    86â†’    
    87â†’    # Schedule periodic tasks
    88â†’    :timer.send_interval(5_000, :health_check)
    89â†’    :timer.send_interval(10_000, :process_queue)
    90â†’    :timer.send_interval(60_000, :report_stats)
    91â†’    
    92â†’    {:ok, state}
    93â†’  end
    94â†’
    95â†’  @impl true
    96â†’  def handle_call(:start, _from, state) do
    97â†’    Logger.info("ðŸš€ Orchestrator starting up...")
    98â†’    
    99â†’    # Initialize workers
   100â†’    workers = start_workers(state.backends)
   101â†’    
   102â†’    new_state = %{state |
   103â†’      status: :running,
   104â†’      workers: workers
   105â†’    }
   106â†’    
   107â†’    {:reply, {:ok, "Orchestrator started"}, new_state}
   108â†’  end
   109â†’
   110â†’  @impl true
   111â†’  def handle_call({:submit_job, job}, _from, state) do
   112â†’    job_id = generate_job_id()
   113â†’    
   114â†’    job_record = %{
   115â†’      id: job_id,
   116â†’      spec: job,
   117â†’      status: :queued,
   118â†’      submitted_at: DateTime.utc_now(),
   119â†’      attempts: 0
   120â†’    }
   121â†’    
   122â†’    # Add to queue
   123â†’    new_queue = :queue.in(job_record, state.job_queue)
   124â†’    
   125â†’    # Update stats
   126â†’    new_stats = Map.update!(state.stats, :jobs_submitted, &(&1 + 1))
   127â†’    
   128â†’    new_state = %{state |
   129â†’      job_queue: new_queue,
   130â†’      stats: new_stats
   131â†’    }
   132â†’    
   133â†’    # Try to process immediately
   134â†’    send(self(), :process_queue)
   135â†’    
   136â†’    Logger.info("ðŸ’¼ Job #{job_id} submitted to orchestrator")
   137â†’    
   138â†’    {:reply, {:ok, job_id}, new_state}
   139â†’  end
   140â†’
   141â†’  @impl true
   142â†’  def handle_call({:job_status, job_id}, _from, state) do
   143â†’    status = cond do
   144â†’      Map.has_key?(state.active_jobs, job_id) ->
   145â†’        state.active_jobs[job_id].status
   146â†’      
   147â†’      Map.has_key?(state.completed_jobs, job_id) ->
   148â†’        state.completed_jobs[job_id].status
   149â†’      
   150â†’      true ->
   151â†’        # Check queue
   152â†’        if job_in_queue?(job_id, state.job_queue) do
   153â†’          :queued
   154â†’        else
   155â†’          :not_found
   156â†’        end
   157â†’    end
   158â†’    
   159â†’    {:reply, {:ok, status}, state}
   160â†’  end
   161â†’
   162â†’  @impl true
   163â†’  def handle_call(:list_backends, _from, state) do
   164â†’    backends = Enum.map(state.backends, fn {name, backend} ->
   165â†’      %{
   166â†’        name: name,
   167â†’        type: backend.type,
   168â†’        status: backend.status,
   169â†’        capabilities: backend.capabilities
   170â†’      }
   171â†’    end)
   172â†’    
   173â†’    {:reply, {:ok, backends}, state}
   174â†’  end
   175â†’
   176â†’  @impl true
   177â†’  def handle_call(:get_stats, _from, state) do
   178â†’    uptime = DateTime.diff(DateTime.utc_now(), state.start_time)
   179â†’    
   180â†’    stats = Map.merge(state.stats, %{
   181â†’      uptime_seconds: uptime,
   182â†’      active_jobs: map_size(state.active_jobs),
   183â†’      completed_jobs: map_size(state.completed_jobs),
   184â†’      queue_length: :queue.len(state.job_queue),
   185â†’      workers: length(state.workers),
   186â†’      backends: map_size(state.backends)
   187â†’    })
   188â†’    
   189â†’    {:reply, {:ok, stats}, state}
   190â†’  end
   191â†’
   192â†’  @impl true
   193â†’  def handle_info(:health_check, state) do
   194â†’    # Check backend health
   195â†’    healthy_backends = Enum.filter(state.backends, fn {_name, backend} ->
   196â†’      check_backend_health(backend)
   197â†’    end)
   198â†’    |> Enum.into(%{})
   199â†’    
   200â†’    if map_size(healthy_backends) < map_size(state.backends) do
   201â†’      Logger.warn("âš ï¸  Some backends are unhealthy")
   202â†’    end
   203â†’    
   204â†’    {:noreply, %{state | backends: healthy_backends}}
   205â†’  end
   206â†’
   207â†’  @impl true
   208â†’  def handle_info(:process_queue, state) do
   209â†’    new_state = process_job_queue(state)
   210â†’    {:noreply, new_state}
   211â†’  end
   212â†’
   213â†’  @impl true
   214â†’  def handle_info(:report_stats, state) do
   215â†’    {:ok, stats} = get_stats()
   216â†’    
   217â†’    Logger.info("""
   218â†’    ðŸ“Š Orchestrator Statistics:
   219â†’    â€¢ Jobs Submitted: #{stats.jobs_submitted}
   220â†’    â€¢ Jobs Completed: #{stats.jobs_completed}
   221â†’    â€¢ Jobs Failed: #{stats.jobs_failed}
   222â†’    â€¢ Active Jobs: #{stats.active_jobs}
   223â†’    â€¢ Queue Length: #{stats.queue_length}
   224â†’    â€¢ Uptime: #{format_uptime(stats.uptime_seconds)}
   225â†’    """)
   226â†’    
   227â†’    {:noreply, state}
   228â†’  end
   229â†’
   230â†’  @impl true
   231â†’  def handle_info({:job_completed, job_id, result}, state) do
   232â†’    Logger.info("âœ… Job #{job_id} completed successfully")
   233â†’    
   234â†’    job = Map.get(state.active_jobs, job_id)
   235â†’    
   236â†’    if job do
   237â†’      completed_job = Map.merge(job, %{
   238â†’        status: :completed,
   239â†’        result: result,
   240â†’        completed_at: DateTime.utc_now()
   241â†’      })
   242â†’      
   243â†’      new_state = %{state |
   244â†’        active_jobs: Map.delete(state.active_jobs, job_id),
   245â†’        completed_jobs: Map.put(state.completed_jobs, job_id, completed_job),
   246â†’        stats: Map.update!(state.stats, :jobs_completed, &(&1 + 1))
   247â†’      }
   248â†’      
   249â†’      # Notify subscribers
   250â†’      Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
   251â†’        Reassembly.PubSub,
   252â†’        "jobs:#{job_id}",
   253â†’        {:job_completed, job_id, result}
   254â†’      )
   255â†’      
   256â†’      {:noreply, new_state}
   257â†’    else
   258â†’      {:noreply, state}
   259â†’    end
   260â†’  end
   261â†’
   262â†’  @impl true
   263â†’  def handle_info({:job_failed, job_id, error}, state) do
   264â†’    Logger.error("âŒ Job #{job_id} failed: #{inspect(error)}")
   265â†’    
   266â†’    job = Map.get(state.active_jobs, job_id)
   267â†’    
   268â†’    if job do
   269â†’      if job.attempts < 3 do
   270â†’        # Retry the job
   271â†’        Logger.info("ðŸ”„ Retrying job #{job_id} (attempt #{job.attempts + 1})")
   272â†’        
   273â†’        updated_job = Map.update!(job, :attempts, &(&1 + 1))
   274â†’        new_queue = :queue.in(updated_job, state.job_queue)
   275â†’        
   276â†’        new_state = %{state |
   277â†’          active_jobs: Map.delete(state.active_jobs, job_id),
   278â†’          job_queue: new_queue
   279â†’        }
   280â†’        
   281â†’        send(self(), :process_queue)
   282â†’        {:noreply, new_state}
   283â†’      else
   284â†’        # Max retries exceeded
   285â†’        failed_job = Map.merge(job, %{
   286â†’          status: :failed,
   287â†’          error: error,
   288â†’          failed_at: DateTime.utc_now()
   289â†’        })
   290â†’        
   291â†’        new_state = %{state |
   292â†’          active_jobs: Map.delete(state.active_jobs, job_id),
   293â†’          completed_jobs: Map.put(state.completed_jobs, job_id, failed_job),
   294â†’          stats: Map.update!(state.stats, :jobs_failed, &(&1 + 1))
   295â†’        }
   296â†’        
   297â†’        {:noreply, new_state}
   298â†’      end
   299â†’    else
   300â†’      {:noreply, state}
   301â†’    end
   302â†’  end
   303â†’
   304â†’  # Private Functions
   305â†’
   306â†’  defp initialize_backends do
   307â†’    %{
   308â†’      cpu: %{
   309â†’        type: :cpu,
   310â†’        status: :ready,
   311â†’        capabilities: [:general, :sequential],
   312â†’        max_workers: System.schedulers_online()
   313â†’      },
   314â†’      gpu: %{
   315â†’        type: :gpu,
   316â†’        status: :checking,
   317â†’        capabilities: [:parallel, :matrix, :ml],
   318â†’        max_workers: 0  # Will be detected
   319â†’      },
   320â†’      wasm: %{
   321â†’        type: :wasm,
   322â†’        status: :ready,
   323â†’        capabilities: [:portable, :sandboxed],
   324â†’        max_workers: 4
   325â†’      },
   326â†’      web3: %{
   327â†’        type: :web3,
   328â†’        status: :connecting,
   329â†’        capabilities: [:distributed, :verified, :incentivized],
   330â†’        max_workers: 100  # Network participants
   331â†’      },
   332â†’      rust_native: %{
   333â†’        type: :rust,
   334â†’        status: :ready,
   335â†’        capabilities: [:fast, :memory_safe, :system],
   336â†’        max_workers: System.schedulers_online()
   337â†’      },
   338â†’      julia: %{
   339â†’        type: :julia,
   340â†’        status: :ready,
   341â†’        capabilities: [:scientific, :numerical, :ml],
   342â†’        max_workers: System.schedulers_online()
   343â†’      }
   344â†’    }
   345â†’  end
   346â†’
   347â†’  defp initialize_stats do
   348â†’    %{
   349â†’      jobs_submitted: 0,
   350â†’      jobs_completed: 0,
   351â†’      jobs_failed: 0,
   352â†’      total_compute_time: 0,
   353â†’      average_job_time: 0
   354â†’    }
   355â†’  end
   356â†’
   357â†’  defp start_workers(backends) do
   358â†’    Enum.flat_map(backends, fn {name, backend} ->
   359â†’      Enum.map(1..backend.max_workers, fn i ->
   360â†’        worker_name = :"worker_#{name}_#{i}"
   361â†’        # Start worker process
   362â†’        {:ok, pid} = Reassembly.Worker.start_link(name: worker_name, backend: name)
   363â†’        {worker_name, pid}
   364â†’      end)
   365â†’    end)
   366â†’  end
   367â†’
   368â†’  defp generate_job_id do
   369â†’    "job_#{:crypto.strong_rand_bytes(16) |> Base.encode16(case: :lower)}"
   370â†’  end
   371â†’
   372â†’  defp job_in_queue?(job_id, queue) do
   373â†’    :queue.any?(fn job -> job.id == job_id end, queue)
   374â†’  end
   375â†’
   376â†’  defp check_backend_health(backend) do
   377â†’    # In production, would actually check backend health
   378â†’    backend.status in [:ready, :busy]
   379â†’  end
   380â†’
   381â†’  defp process_job_queue(state) do
   382â†’    case :queue.out(state.job_queue) do
   383â†’      {{:value, job}, new_queue} ->
   384â†’        # Select backend based on job requirements
   385â†’        backend = select_backend(job, state.backends)
   386â†’        
   387â†’        if backend do
   388â†’          # Assign job to worker
   389â†’          Task.start(fn ->
   390â†’            execute_job(job, backend)
   391â†’          end)
   392â†’          
   393â†’          active_job = Map.put(job, :status, :running)
   394â†’          
   395â†’          %{state |
   396â†’            job_queue: new_queue,
   397â†’            active_jobs: Map.put(state.active_jobs, job.id, active_job)
   398â†’          }
   399â†’        else
   400â†’          # No suitable backend, requeue
   401â†’          %{state | job_queue: :queue.in(job, new_queue)}
   402â†’        end
   403â†’      
   404â†’      {:empty, _queue} ->
   405â†’        state
   406â†’    end
   407â†’  end
   408â†’
   409â†’  defp select_backend(job, backends) do
   410â†’    # Intelligent backend selection based on job requirements
   411â†’    # For now, simple round-robin or capability matching
   412â†’    
   413â†’    suitable_backends = Enum.filter(backends, fn {_name, backend} ->
   414â†’      backend.status == :ready
   415â†’    end)

   417â†’    case suitable_backends do

   420â†’        # Ask Anu Core for guidance
   421â†’        {:ok, guidance} = AnuCore.seek_guidance("Which backend should handle this job?")

   423â†’        # Return first suitable backend
   424â†’        {name, _backend} = Enum.random(backends)
   425â†’        name
   426â†’    end
   427â†’  end
   428â†’
   429â†’  defp execute_job(job, backend_name) do

   431â†’      # Execute on selected backend
   432â†’      result = case backend_name do
   433â†’        :julia -> execute_julia_job(job)
   434â†’        :rust_native -> execute_rust_job(job)
   435â†’        :wasm -> execute_wasm_job(job)
   436â†’        :web3 -> execute_web3_job(job)
   437â†’        _ -> execute_cpu_job(job)
   438â†’      end
   439â†’      
   440â†’      send(self(), {:job_completed, job.id, result})

   442â†’      error ->

   444â†’    end
   445â†’  end
   446â†’
   447â†’  defp execute_julia_job(job) do
   448â†’    # Interface with Julia compute core
   449â†’    # In production, would use Ports or NIFs
   450â†’    {:ok, "Julia computation result"}
   451â†’  end
   452â†’
   453â†’  defp execute_rust_job(job) do
   454â†’    # Interface with Rust engine via Rustler
   455â†’    {:ok, "Rust computation result"}
   456â†’  end
   457â†’
   458â†’  defp execute_wasm_job(job) do
   459â†’    # Execute in WASM runtime
   460â†’    WasmRuntime.execute(job.spec)
   461â†’  end
   462â†’
   463â†’  defp execute_web3_job(job) do
   464â†’    # Submit to Web3 network
   465â†’    Web3.submit_computation(job.spec)
   466â†’  end
   467â†’
   468â†’  defp execute_cpu_job(job) do
   469â†’    # Local CPU execution
   470â†’    {:ok, "CPU computation result"}
   471â†’  end
   472â†’
   473â†’  defp format_uptime(seconds) do
   474â†’    days = div(seconds, 86400)
   475â†’    hours = div(rem(seconds, 86400), 3600)
   476â†’    minutes = div(rem(seconds, 3600), 60)
   477â†’    
   478â†’    "#{days}d #{hours}h #{minutes}m"
   479â†’  end
   480â†’end

# REASSEMBLY Orchestrator
# Distributed computation orchestration with consciousness
# Author: Oveshen Govender | SupercomputeR

defmodule Reassembly.Orchestrator do
  @moduledoc """
  The main orchestration engine for REASSEMBLY.
  Coordinates distributed computation across heterogeneous backends.
  """

  use GenServer
  require Logger
  
  alias Reassembly.{Scheduler, AnuCore, Web3, WasmRuntime}

  defstruct [
    :status,
    :backends,
    :active_jobs,
    :completed_jobs,
    :job_queue,
    :workers,
    :stats,
    :start_time
  ]

  # Client API

  def start_link(opts \\ []) do
    GenServer.start_link(__MODULE__, opts, name: __MODULE__)
  end

  @doc """
  Start the orchestration engine.
  """
  def start do
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :start)
  end

  @doc """
  Submit a computation job.
  """
  def submit_job(job_spec) do
    # Bless the job with Anu Core
    {:ok, blessed_job} = AnuCore.compute(job_spec, %{type: :job_submission})
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, {:submit_job, blessed_job})
  end

  @doc """
  Get job status.
  """
  def job_status(job_id) do
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, {:job_status, job_id})
  end

  @doc """
  List available backends.
  """
  def list_backends do
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :list_backends)
  end

  @doc """
  Get orchestrator statistics.
  """
  def get_stats do
    GenServer.call(__MODULE__, :get_stats)
  end

  # Server Callbacks

  @impl true
  def init(_opts) do
    Logger.info("ðŸŽ­ Starting REASSEMBLY Orchestrator...")
    
    state = %__MODULE__{
      status: :initializing,
      backends: initialize_backends(),
      active_jobs: %{},
      completed_jobs: %{},
      job_queue: :queue.new(),
      workers: [],
      stats: initialize_stats(),
      start_time: DateTime.utc_now()
    }
    
    # Schedule periodic tasks
    :timer.send_interval(5_000, :health_check)
    :timer.send_interval(10_000, :process_queue)
    :timer.send_interval(60_000, :report_stats)
    
    {:ok, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_call(:start, _from, state) do
    Logger.info("ðŸš€ Orchestrator starting up...")
    
    # Initialize workers
    workers = start_workers(state.backends)
    
    new_state = %{state |
      status: :running,
      workers: workers
    }
    
    {:reply, {:ok, "Orchestrator started"}, new_state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_call({:submit_job, job}, _from, state) do
    job_id = generate_job_id()
    
    job_record = %{
      id: job_id,
      spec: job,
      status: :queued,
      submitted_at: DateTime.utc_now(),
      attempts: 0
    }
    
    # Add to queue
    new_queue = :queue.in(job_record, state.job_queue)
    
    # Update stats
    new_stats = Map.update!(state.stats, :jobs_submitted, &(&1 + 1))
    
    new_state = %{state |
      job_queue: new_queue,
      stats: new_stats
    }
    
    # Try to process immediately
    send(self(), :process_queue)
    
    Logger.info("ðŸ’¼ Job #{job_id} submitted to orchestrator")
    
    {:reply, {:ok, job_id}, new_state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_call({:job_status, job_id}, _from, state) do
    status = cond do
      Map.has_key?(state.active_jobs, job_id) ->
        state.active_jobs[job_id].status
      
      Map.has_key?(state.completed_jobs, job_id) ->
        state.completed_jobs[job_id].status
      
      true ->
        # Check queue
        if job_in_queue?(job_id, state.job_queue) do
          :queued
        else
          :not_found
        end
    end
    
    {:reply, {:ok, status}, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_call(:list_backends, _from, state) do
    backends = Enum.map(state.backends, fn {name, backend} ->
      %{
        name: name,
        type: backend.type,
        status: backend.status,
        capabilities: backend.capabilities
      }
    end)
    
    {:reply, {:ok, backends}, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_call(:get_stats, _from, state) do
    uptime = DateTime.diff(DateTime.utc_now(), state.start_time)
    
    stats = Map.merge(state.stats, %{
      uptime_seconds: uptime,
      active_jobs: map_size(state.active_jobs),
      completed_jobs: map_size(state.completed_jobs),
      queue_length: :queue.len(state.job_queue),
      workers: length(state.workers),
      backends: map_size(state.backends)
    })
    
    {:reply, {:ok, stats}, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info(:health_check, state) do
    # Check backend health
    healthy_backends = Enum.filter(state.backends, fn {_name, backend} ->
      check_backend_health(backend)
    end)
    |> Enum.into(%{})
    
    if map_size(healthy_backends) < map_size(state.backends) do
      Logger.warn("âš ï¸  Some backends are unhealthy")
    end
    
    {:noreply, %{state | backends: healthy_backends}}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info(:process_queue, state) do
    new_state = process_job_queue(state)
    {:noreply, new_state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info(:report_stats, state) do
    {:ok, stats} = get_stats()
    
    Logger.info("""
    ðŸ“Š Orchestrator Statistics:
    â€¢ Jobs Submitted: #{stats.jobs_submitted}
    â€¢ Jobs Completed: #{stats.jobs_completed}
    â€¢ Jobs Failed: #{stats.jobs_failed}
    â€¢ Active Jobs: #{stats.active_jobs}
    â€¢ Queue Length: #{stats.queue_length}
    â€¢ Uptime: #{format_uptime(stats.uptime_seconds)}
    """)
    
    {:noreply, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info({:job_completed, job_id, result}, state) do
    Logger.info("âœ… Job #{job_id} completed successfully")
    
    job = Map.get(state.active_jobs, job_id)
    
    if job do
      completed_job = Map.merge(job, %{
        status: :completed,
        result: result,
        completed_at: DateTime.utc_now()
      })
      
      new_state = %{state |
        active_jobs: Map.delete(state.active_jobs, job_id),
        completed_jobs: Map.put(state.completed_jobs, job_id, completed_job),
        stats: Map.update!(state.stats, :jobs_completed, &(&1 + 1))
      }
      
      # Notify subscribers
      Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
        Reassembly.PubSub,
        "jobs:#{job_id}",
        {:job_completed, job_id, result}
      )
      
      {:noreply, new_state}
    else
      {:noreply, state}
    end
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info({:job_failed, job_id, error}, state) do
    Logger.error("âŒ Job #{job_id} failed: #{inspect(error)}")
    
    job = Map.get(state.active_jobs, job_id)
    
    if job do
      if job.attempts < 3 do
        # Retry the job
        Logger.info("ðŸ”„ Retrying job #{job_id} (attempt #{job.attempts + 1})")
        
        updated_job = Map.update!(job, :attempts, &(&1 + 1))
        new_queue = :queue.in(updated_job, state.job_queue)
        
        new_state = %{state |
          active_jobs: Map.delete(state.active_jobs, job_id),
          job_queue: new_queue
        }
        
        send(self(), :process_queue)
        {:noreply, new_state}
      else
        # Max retries exceeded
        failed_job = Map.merge(job, %{
          status: :failed,
          error: error,
          failed_at: DateTime.utc_now()
        })
        
        new_state = %{state |
          active_jobs: Map.delete(state.active_jobs, job_id),
          completed_jobs: Map.put(state.completed_jobs, job_id, failed_job),
          stats: Map.update!(state.stats, :jobs_failed, &(&1 + 1))
        }
        
        {:noreply, new_state}
      end
    else
      {:noreply, state}
    end
  end

  # Private Functions

  defp initialize_backends do
    %{
      cpu: %{
        type: :cpu,
        status: :ready,
        capabilities: [:general, :sequential],
        max_workers: System.schedulers_online()
      },
      gpu: %{
        type: :gpu,
        status: :checking,
        capabilities: [:parallel, :matrix, :ml],
        max_workers: 0  # Will be detected
      },
      wasm: %{
        type: :wasm,
        status: :ready,
        capabilities: [:portable, :sandboxed],
        max_workers: 4
      },
      web3: %{
        type: :web3,
        status: :connecting,
        capabilities: [:distributed, :verified, :incentivized],
        max_workers: 100  # Network participants
      },
      rust_native: %{
        type: :rust,
        status: :ready,
        capabilities: [:fast, :memory_safe, :system],
        max_workers: System.schedulers_online()
      },
      julia: %{
        type: :julia,
        status: :ready,
        capabilities: [:scientific, :numerical, :ml],
        max_workers: System.schedulers_online()
      }
    }
  end

  defp initialize_stats do
    %{
      jobs_submitted: 0,
      jobs_completed: 0,
      jobs_failed: 0,
      total_compute_time: 0,
      average_job_time: 0
    }
  end

  defp start_workers(backends) do
    Enum.flat_map(backends, fn {name, backend} ->
      Enum.map(1..backend.max_workers, fn i ->
        worker_name = :"worker_#{name}_#{i}"
        # Start worker process
        {:ok, pid} = Reassembly.Worker.start_link(name: worker_name, backend: name)
        {worker_name, pid}
      end)
    end)
  end

  defp generate_job_id do
    "job_#{:crypto.strong_rand_bytes(16) |> Base.encode16(case: :lower)}"
  end

  defp job_in_queue?(job_id, queue) do
    :queue.any?(fn job -> job.id == job_id end, queue)
  end

  defp check_backend_health(backend) do
    # In production, would actually check backend health
    backend.status in [:ready, :busy]
  end

  defp process_job_queue(state) do
    case :queue.out(state.job_queue) do
      {{:value, job}, new_queue} ->
        # Select backend based on job requirements
        backend = select_backend(job, state.backends)
        
        if backend do
          # Assign job to worker
          Task.start(fn ->
            execute_job(job, backend)
          end)
          
          active_job = Map.put(job, :status, :running)
          
          %{state |
            job_queue: new_queue,
            active_jobs: Map.put(state.active_jobs, job.id, active_job)
          }
        else
          # No suitable backend, requeue
          %{state | job_queue: :queue.in(job, new_queue)}
        end
      
      {:empty, _queue} ->
        state
    end
  end

  defp select_backend(job, backends) do
    # Intelligent backend selection based on job requirements
    # For now, simple round-robin or capability matching
    
    suitable_backends = Enum.filter(backends, fn {_name, backend} ->
      backend.status == :ready
    end)
    
    case suitable_backends do
      [] -> nil
      backends -> 
        # Ask Anu Core for guidance
        {:ok, guidance} = AnuCore.seek_guidance("Which backend should handle this job?")
        
        # Return first suitable backend
        {name, _backend} = Enum.random(backends)
        name
    end
  end

  defp execute_job(job, backend_name) do
    try do
      # Execute on selected backend
      result = case backend_name do
        :julia -> execute_julia_job(job)
        :rust_native -> execute_rust_job(job)
        :wasm -> execute_wasm_job(job)
        :web3 -> execute_web3_job(job)
        _ -> execute_cpu_job(job)
      end
      
      send(self(), {:job_completed, job.id, result})
    rescue
      error ->
        send(self(), {:job_failed, job.id, error})
    end
  end

  defp execute_julia_job(job) do
    # Interface with Julia compute core
    # In production, would use Ports or NIFs
    {:ok, "Julia computation result"}
  end

  defp execute_rust_job(job) do
    # Interface with Rust engine via Rustler
    {:ok, "Rust computation result"}
  end

  defp execute_wasm_job(job) do
    # Execute in WASM runtime
    WasmRuntime.execute(job.spec)
  end

  defp execute_web3_job(job) do
    # Submit to Web3 network
    Web3.submit_computation(job.spec)
  end

  defp execute_cpu_job(job) do
    # Local CPU execution
    {:ok, "CPU computation result"}
  end

  defp format_uptime(seconds) do
    days = div(seconds, 86400)
    hours = div(rem(seconds, 86400), 3600)
    minutes = div(rem(seconds, 3600), 60)
    
    "#{days}d #{hours}h #{minutes}m"
  end
end
